docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
CPU, Memory, Cache and Disks

These practical exercises are intended to get you to do initial reconnaissance of - Processor - Cache - Main Memory. - Disks

I also get you to look at predictive failure analysis for disk...you might want to read above the efficay of this. It sounds great, does it work?

I cover the CPU hardware technology in another module, if you have not yet covered this, discuss with your lecturer.

docs.title: BIOS/UEFI settings
docs.text:
If you are not familiar with BIOS and UEFI, do a little background reading now.

In this exercise , we will look at some basic tools for reconnaissance of main memory.

  1. You may carry out this step on your own computer ONLY.
  2. Boot your personal computer and enter BIOS/UEFI, do not change any settings.

  3. Locate all the information you can relating to memory and cache, explain and document it.

  4. It is always good to be able to identify memory components and configuration remotely, or without powering down the machine and dismantling.

  5. In the search box of the OS, type System and open the System Information dialog.
  6. Locate all the information you can relating to memory and cache, explain and document it.
Fig 1. System Information.
  1. You can do a more detailed analysis using tools. A very common tool used is CPU-Z.
  2. Locate and download a copy of CPU-Z.
  3. You may NOT install this on a lab PC. Alternatively, it is a small application you may install on your home computer or preferably, a VM.
  4. Map out the CPU, memory and cache in your computer, identifying all components in detail.

docs.title: Diskpart
docs.text:
Create a Windows VM for the next exercises.

One of the most fundamental tools for working with disks is Microsoft’s diskpart. Be careful, a mistake here may render your disks unreadable.

  1. Open a command prompt as administrator
  2. Run diskpart
  3. Type ? to get help. Read through the options and understand them.
Fig 2. DISKPART.
  1. If the meaning of any command is unclear, type the command followed by a question mark, to get help.
Fig 3. Output of list ?.
  1. Type the command list disk to identify every disk in the system. Document these disks for your own system before continuing.
Fig 4. Output of list disk.

docs.title: Making virtual disks
docs.text:
1. Look up help for the create command.
  2. Create a virtual hard drive on a suitable volume at the command prompt. You can use a USB key as a target disk if you require. My F: drive has space free, I used the command
create vdisk file=f:\techcp901.vhd maximum=1500

to create a 1.5GB disk file. It will take a few minutes.

  1. We select the disk by typing the command 
    select vdisk file=f:\techcp901.vhd
  2. We can now mount this to the system by typing the command 
    attach vdisk
  3. The command 
    list disk
    should now show the new volume. In my case, its disk 8.
Fig 5. Final list disk.

The Asterix on the left shows which disk is selected and active.

docs.title: Disk Sector Editor
docs.text:
You can use the disk sector editor of your choice, but WinHex is a free download.

  1. Open WinHex as administrator. You normally do this by right-clicking.
  2. Using WinHex, open the VHD file created previously.
  3. If you examine the file, it should be completely empty. Beware, with other virtual disk formats, a blank disk may not be blank, there could be header information in the raw file associated with the VHD format itself.
Fig 6. WinHex.
  1. Close WinHex.
  2. Run again diskpart as administrator.
  3. Carefully list and select the correct disk.
Fig 7. Select disk.

  1. Check to see what the ID is of your virtual disk, mine is disk 8. In diskpart, type the command 

    select disk 8
convert mbr
    which should create an MBR partition table in the first sector. The layout of this will be discussed in lectures. Open WinHex as administrator and this time, open the disk, not the file (F9). Document it.

  2. In diskpart, type the command 

    clean
    and re-examine the disk. What happened?

  3. In diskpart, type the command 

    convert gpt
    again to create a partition table. Then type the commands 
    create partition primary
list partition

  4. Open WinHex as administrator and open the disk, not the file (F9). Where should the new partition start? Is there anything there? Document it.

  5. Type the command

``` select partition 1 active ```` to enable it as bootable. Once more, examine with WinHex. Where should the new partition start? Is there anything there?

  1. To create a file system, type

format FS=NTFS label=TECHCP901 quick and when complete, examine with WinHex. Where should the new file system start? Is there anything there?

docs.title: SMART
docs.text:
You should carry these exercises out on a real physical machine if possible, VMs do not show SMART counters.

You may not install software in the computer labs.

Find a free SMART tool monitor online. I use Crystal Disk Info but use the one from your own hard disk manufacturer.

Fig 8. Crystal Disk Info.

I have installed a basic disk utility, almost every hard disk manufacturer has their own. Ideally, you should use the tool for the disk in your own system; e.g. a tool from Seagate, Hitachi, Western Digital, etc.

Locate the tool, install it and test your system. My system is showing six hard drives, a mixture of HDDs and SSDs. If you have an SSD, some of the counters will give you meaningless data.

But what are these values, what do they mean, are they significant?

Firstly, do some background reading and understand what SMART is and why it may be important. Then find a list of the attributes reported and what they mean. See if you can locate any good reference which tell you what attributes to monitor and whether you can do predictive failure analysis on that basis.

This module does NOT assume a knowledge of Linux; however, I am going to ask you to look up a basic tool used in Linux systems for SMART. Find smartmontools, understand what they are.

In data centre environments, I would use these in Linux for predictive failure analysis. Knowing which attributes to consider and what the numbers mean, that’s the challenge!
